text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that parody is much more likely to be considered fair use than satire because parody transforms the work itself, whereas satire just places the work in a different context. The candidate answer discusses the parody defense in both Italy (Art. 70) and the U.S. (Fair Use, Section 107), but it never makes the specific distinction between parody and satire as described in the criterion (i.e., that parody transforms the work while satire only changes context). The answer focuses on the commercial nature of the infringement being detrimental to the parody defense in both jurisdictions.", "criterion_id": "c11709a9-5dda-48c9-ac5e-05eb4cb06143"}
